questions.question: What does camera metering do?
options: Measures light reflected from the scene to suggest exposure settings
questions.reviewHint: Metering basics—the meter reads reflected light and guides exposure.

questions.question: Evaluative/Matrix metering is best described as…
options: A tiny spot at the focus point
The camera looks at the whole frame and balances it for a general scene
questions.reviewHint: Matrix/Evaluative—good all-rounder that considers most of the frame.

questions.question: Center-weighted metering means…
options: Only 1–5% of the frame is measured
The center area is given more importance, with the rest averaged in
The whole frame is treated equally
It only works in Manual mode
questions.reviewHint: Center-weighted—prioritizes the middle while still considering the surroundings.

questions.question: Spot metering…
options: Measures a very small area (≈1–5%), often at the focus point or center
questions.reviewHint: Spot—tiny area reading; great for tricky lighting on faces or small subjects.

questions.question: Your subject is backlit and looks dark in Evaluative/Matrix. Quickest fix without changing mode?
questions.reviewHint: Backlit + EC—add +EV so the face isn't a silhouette.

questions.question: You meter off a very dark coat with Spot. If you trust that reading without compensation, the photo will likely be…
options: Too bright (the meter tries to make it mid-gray)
questions.reviewHint: Subject tones—dark things get over-bright unless you add negative EC.

questions.question: Why does snow or a white beach often look gray when you rely on the meter?
options: The meter assumes what it sees should be mid-gray
questions.reviewHint: 18% gray idea—add +EC for bright scenes to keep whites white.

questions.question: What does *AE-Lock (AEL / ) do?
options: Locks the exposure you just metered so you can recompose
questions.reviewHint: AE-Lock—meter from the right place, lock exposure, then recompose.

questions.question: Small bird against a bright sky—which metering helps you expose the bird?
questions.reviewHint: Small subject + bright background—Spot meter the subject.

questions.question: After metering and shooting, what's the best check to avoid clipping?
questions.reviewHint: Histogram—use it to see if tones are crushed or blown.

questions.question: In Manual mode (Auto ISO OFF), the meter mainly…
options: Shows where you are vs. "metered" exposure—you adjust the triangle
Applies exposure compensation on its own
questions.reviewHint: Manual + meter—it's a guide; you move shutter/aperture/ISO.

questions.question: When might Center-weighted be a smart choice?
options: Portraits where the subject is near the middle and background varies
Cityscapes with even light across the frame
questions.reviewHint: Choosing modes—center-weighted is simple and reliable for centered subjects.
